title: [Neuroscience] When we see what others do, our brain sees not what we see, but what we expect: If we observe actions in meaningful sequences, our brains increasingly ignore what comes into our eyes, and depend more on predictions of what should happen next, derived from our own motor system

[Neuroscience] In VR experiments, when subjects touched their own bodies with a virtual object, it led to a tingling sensation where the avatar was touched, even though there was no real physical contact between the virtual object and the body. Researchers describe this phenomenon as a phantom touch illusion.
